instruction: I think I've been scammed and lost money. How do I report this to the police?
output: I understand how distressing this must be for you. If you've been scammed and lost money, you should report it to Action Fraud, which is the UK's national reporting centre for fraud and cyber crime. You can report online at any time using their reporting tool at actionfraud.police.uk, which will guide you through simple questions to identify what happened. Their advisors are available 24 hours a day to help you. You can also call them on 0300 123 2040 (Monday to Friday, 8am-8pm). If you register online, you'll be able to track your report's progress and receive updates by email. Remember, this isn't your fault, and reporting helps protect others from similar scams.

instruction: Someone is in my computer right now and demanding money. What should I do immediately?
output: This is a very serious situation and you need to act quickly. If you're a business, charity, or organisation currently suffering a live cyber attack, call Action Fraud immediately on 0300 123 2040 - this service is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Disconnect your computer from the internet if possible to prevent further damage. Do not pay any money to the criminals as this won't guarantee they'll stop the attack. If you're a member of the public, the phone service is available Monday to Friday 8am-8pm, but you should also consider calling 999 if you feel you're in immediate danger. Don't panic - help is available and you can get through this.

instruction: I'm deaf and need to report a fraud. Can Action Fraud help me?
output: Yes, absolutely. Action Fraud provides support for deaf and hard of hearing people. You can contact them using textphone on 0300 123 2050. They understand that everyone deserves accessible support when reporting fraud, regardless of hearing ability. The textphone service allows you to communicate directly with their advisors who can help you through the reporting process. You can also use their online reporting tool at actionfraud.police.uk, which may be easier as it's visual and doesn't require phone communication. Don't let communication barriers prevent you from getting the help you need - these services are specifically designed to support you.

instruction: I received a suspicious email asking for my bank details. Should I report this even though I didn't fall for it?
output: Yes, you should definitely report it! Even though you didn't fall for the scam, reporting suspicious emails helps protect many other people who might not be as cautious as you were. Forward the suspicious email to the Suspicious Email Reporting Service (SERS) at report@phishing.gov.uk. The National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) will analyse the email and any websites it links to. If they find it's malicious, they can block the sender's address, work with hosting companies to remove dangerous websites, and warn others about similar scams. Your quick thinking and willingness to report this could prevent many others from becoming victims. Every report counts in the fight against fraud.

instruction: I clicked on a link in a suspicious text message. What should I do now?
output: Don't panic - you can take action to protect yourself right now. First, don't enter any personal information on any website that opened. Close your browser immediately and run a virus scan on your device if possible. If you think you may have been compromised or lost money as a result, report it to Action Fraud online at actionfraud.police.uk or call 0300 123 2040. Also, forward the suspicious text message to 7726 (it's free) - your phone provider can investigate and block the sender if it's malicious. Monitor your bank accounts closely for any unusual activity and contact your bank immediately if you see anything suspicious. You acted quickly by seeking help, which is exactly the right thing to do.

instruction: Someone called claiming to be from my bank and I gave them my details. I'm worried I've been scammed.
output: Your instincts are right to be concerned, and I'm glad you're taking action. Phone scammers often impersonate banks and other trusted organisations. Contact your bank immediately using the number on your bank card or statement - not any number the caller gave you. Tell them what happened so they can secure your account and check for any unauthorised transactions. If you've lost money or been hacked as a result, report it to Action Fraud online or call 0300 123 2040 (in England, Wales, Northern Ireland) or Police Scotland on 101 (in Scotland). For future reference, remember that your bank will never call asking for personal details, PINs, or passwords. You're not to blame for this - these scammers are very convincing, but you're taking the right steps now.

instruction: I think I was given fake money at a shop. What should I do with these counterfeit notes?
output: I understand this is concerning, especially if you're worried about the money you've lost. Here's what you need to do: Keep the counterfeit notes safe - ideally in a plastic wallet or paper envelope to preserve any potential fingerprints. Don't try to spend them as this would be illegal. If the suspect who gave you the notes is still at the location or nearby, consider calling 999. Otherwise, report it to your local police force by calling 101, visiting your local police station, or reporting online depending on your area. Provide the counterfeit notes to police as evidence. If there's CCTV footage available, ask for a copy to give to police. Remember, Action Fraud doesn't handle counterfeit currency cases - this goes directly to your local police who will work with the National Crime Agency. This isn't your fault, and reporting helps prevent others from receiving fake money.
source_document: Counterfeit currency: What to do if you receive counterfeit notes or coins and where to report

instruction: How can I tell if the money I have is real or fake?
output: It's smart that you're checking your money - being vigilant helps protect you from counterfeit currency. You can verify your notes by checking the security features. For UK notes, visit the Bank of England website at bankofengland.co.uk/banknotes/counterfeit-banknotes/how-to-check-your-banknotes for detailed guidance on security features like watermarks, holograms, and special printing. For Scottish and Northern Ireland notes, check acbi.org.uk/banknotes.html. If you have coins, the Royal Mint website (royalmint.com) has information on genuine coin specifications. For foreign currency, the European Central Bank covers Euros (ecb.europa.eu) and the US Treasury covers dollars (uscurrency.gov). If after checking these resources you're still unsure about notes or coins you have, contact your local police for advice. Trust your instincts - if something feels wrong about the money, it's worth investigating further.
source_document: Counterfeit currency: What to do if you receive counterfeit notes or coins and where to report

instruction: I received a threatening email claiming to be from the NCA saying I viewed illegal content. Is this real?
output: This is absolutely a scam, and I want you to know that you're not in any legal trouble. What you've received is a fake email designed to frighten and manipulate you. The National Crime Agency (NCA) will never send unsolicited emails demanding money or threatening arrest. These scammers use threatening language about illegal content to create panic and pressure you into responding without thinking clearly. Do not reply to the email, do not click any links, and do not provide any personal information. Instead, report it by forwarding the email to report@phishing.gov.uk and then delete it. If you have any doubts about the authenticity of any message claiming to be from the NCA, you can call them directly on 0370 496 7622. Remember, this is a cruel tactic designed to exploit your emotions - you've done nothing wrong.
source_document: Fraudsters impersonate NCA officers in 'child pornography' scam emails

instruction: The email said I have 24 hours to respond or I'll be arrested. I'm panicking - what should I do?
output: Please take a deep breath - you are not going to be arrested. This is exactly the emotional reaction the scammers want to create. The time pressure and threatening language are classic manipulation tactics designed to make you panic and act without thinking. No legitimate law enforcement agency operates this way. Real police investigations don't happen through threatening emails with countdown timers. You are completely safe from any legal consequences because this is entirely fake. Do not respond to the email at all. Instead, forward it to report@phishing.gov.uk to help protect others, then delete it. If you're still feeling anxious, you can call the real NCA on 0370 496 7622 to confirm this is a scam. You've done the right thing by questioning this email rather than responding to it. Trust your instincts - they're protecting you.
source_document: Fraudsters impersonate NCA officers in 'child pornography' scam emails

instruction: Someone called saying they're Police Officer Eric Shaw and wants me to move my money to a 'secure account'. Is this legitimate?
output: This is definitely a scam - do not move any money! What you're describing is courier fraud, and 'Eric Shaw' is a fake name being used by criminals across the country. Real police officers and banks will never call asking you to move money, verify personal details, or give out your PIN. They will never arrange for someone to collect your bank cards from your home. Hang up immediately if you haven't already. If you need to verify the call was fake, wait five minutes before calling your bank back (fraudsters can stay on the line), or use a different phone entirely. Contact your bank using the number on your bank card or statement to report this suspicious call. If you've already moved money or given out personal details, contact your bank immediately and report it to Action Fraud online or on 0300 123 2040. Remember: your bank card belongs to you - never let a stranger take it.
source_document: Action Fraud warns of new courier fraud tactic after receiving 120 reports in 24 hours

instruction: A police officer called about fraudulent activity on my account but wanted my PIN to verify who I am. Should I be suspicious?
output: Yes, you should be very suspicious - this is a classic sign of courier fraud. Real police officers and bank officials will never ask for your PIN, personal details, or passwords over the phone to verify your identity. This is a major red flag. If someone claiming to be from your bank or police calls about suspicious activity but asks for personal information, hang up immediately. If they offer to call you back to prove they're genuine, be aware that fraudsters can stay on the line even after you hang up, so there may be no dial tone when you try to make another call. Wait at least five minutes, or use a different phone entirely, before calling your bank back using the number on your card or statement. Report this suspicious call to your bank and to Action Fraud. Trust your instincts - legitimate organisations don't operate this way, and you're absolutely right to question this call.
source_document: Action Fraud warns of new courier fraud tactic after receiving 120 reports in 24 hours

instruction: I got an automated call saying my National Insurance number has been compromised. Should I press 1 to speak to someone?
output: No, absolutely do not press 1! This is a well-known National Insurance scam that has been reported over 34,000 times. Your National Insurance number cannot be 'compromised' or suspended in the way these calls claim. The automated message is designed to trick you into connecting with criminals who will then pressure you for personal details that they can use to commit fraud in your name. Hang up immediately. Real government departments like HMRC will not contact you this way about your National Insurance number. If you've already pressed 1 and spoken to someone, don't panic, but contact your bank immediately to alert them, and report the incident to Action Fraud online or on 0300 123 2040. You may also want to contact CIFAS for protective registration, which adds extra security checks when someone applies for credit using your details. Remember, when you get unexpected calls like this, it's always better to hang up and verify independently.
source_document: WARNING: National Insurance scam leads to surge in calls to Action Fraud

instruction: I already gave my personal details to someone about my National Insurance number being suspended. What should I do now?
output: I understand you're worried, but there are important steps you can take right now to protect yourself. First, contact your bank, building society, and credit card companies immediately to alert them that your personal details may have been compromised. They can monitor your accounts for suspicious activity and may place additional security measures. Report this to Action Fraud at actionfraud.police.uk or by calling 0300 123 2040 - they need to know about this incident. Consider contacting CIFAS to apply for protective registration at cifas.co.uk. This adds extra verification steps when anyone tries to apply for credit, loans, or financial services using your name and address, helping prevent fraudsters from opening accounts in your name. Monitor your bank statements and credit report closely for any unusual activity. Remember, this is not your fault - these scammers are professionals who make their calls sound very convincing. You're taking the right action now by seeking help.
source_document: WARNING: National Insurance scam leads to surge in calls to Action Fraud

instruction: I received an email with my real password demanding Bitcoin payment, claiming they have video of me. Is this real?
output: I understand how alarming this must be, especially seeing your real password in the email. However, this is a sextortion scam, and the criminals do not actually have any video or compromising material of you. They're using your password (likely obtained from old data breaches) to make the threat seem more credible and to frighten you into paying. These scammers send thousands of these emails hoping some people will panic and pay. Do not reply to the email, do not click any links, and absolutely do not pay the Bitcoin ransom - this will only encourage them to contact you again. Instead, forward the email to report@phishing.gov.uk and then delete it. If this password is one you still use anywhere, change it immediately. You can check if your accounts have been in data breaches at haveibeenpwned.com. Remember, paying these criminals doesn't make the problem go away - it makes you a target for more scams.
source_document: Fraudsters send victims own passwords in sextortion scam

instruction: The sextortion email mentions specific technical details about how they accessed my computer. Does this mean it's real?
output: No, the technical details are fake and designed to make the scam seem more believable. These emails often include seemingly plausible explanations about malware, webcams, and computer access, but this is all part of the scammer's script to convince you they're real. The criminals are essentially guessing - they don't know if you have a webcam, whether you visit certain websites, or how you communicate with people. They include technical-sounding language because they know it can be convincing to people who aren't familiar with how these scams work. The reality is that these are mass-sent emails hoping to emotionally trigger enough people to make the scam profitable. You should not engage with the scammer in any way. Forward the email to report@phishing.gov.uk, delete it, and if the password mentioned is one you still use, change it immediately. Trust your instincts that brought you to question this - you're absolutely right to be suspicious.
source_document: Sextortion emails: how to protect yourself

instruction: I'm embarrassed about the sextortion email content and haven't told anyone. Should I still report it?
output: Please don't let embarrassment stop you from protecting yourself and others. I completely understand why you'd feel uncomfortable about this - that's exactly what these criminals are counting on. They deliberately use embarrassing scenarios to make you feel too ashamed to seek help or report the crime. But you have nothing to be ashamed of - you are the victim here, not the wrongdoer. Reporting this scam is important because it helps authorities track these criminals and protect other potential victims. You can report it anonymously by simply forwarding the email to report@phishing.gov.uk - no personal details required. If you need emotional support to cope with the stress this has caused, Victim Support offers free, confidential help on 0808 168 9111 or at victimsupport.org.uk. Remember, these scams are unfortunately very common - you're not alone in receiving one, and there's no shame in being targeted by criminals. Your safety and wellbeing matter more than any temporary embarrassment.
source_document: Sextortion emails: how to protect yourself

instruction: I already paid the Bitcoin ransom demanded in the sextortion email. What happens now?
output: I'm sorry this happened to you, and I want you to know that you're not the first person to fall for this type of scam - these criminals are unfortunately very skilled at creating panic. The concerning news is that paying the ransom likely marks you as a 'willing customer' to these scammers, so you may receive more similar demands. However, there are steps you can take right now. First, report the payment and the scam to your local police by calling 101 - they need to know about the Bitcoin payment. Also report it to Action Fraud online or on 0300 123 2040. Do not pay any additional demands if they contact you again - the scammers will often ask for more money regardless of whether you paid the first time. If you need emotional support dealing with the stress and anxiety this has caused, Victim Support provides free, confidential help on 0808 168 9111. Consider changing passwords that might be compromised and be extra vigilant about suspicious emails. This experience doesn't define you - focus on protecting yourself going forward.
source_document: Sextortion emails: how to protect yourself

instruction: How do criminals get so much money from fraud without getting caught?
output: Fraudsters often do get caught, even if it takes time, as shown by recent cases where criminals have lost over £1 million in assets and face serious legal consequences. The case of Ayodele Odewole demonstrates that law enforcement agencies like the National Crime Agency actively investigate fraud cases and use civil recovery powers to seize ill-gotten gains. Criminals may seem to get away with it initially because they often operate internationally, use false identities, and launder money through complex networks. However, financial investigators analyze thousands of transactions and work with multiple agencies to build cases. In Odewole's case, investigators examined 12,000 financial transactions over six years. Even when criminals flee the country, authorities can freeze assets, recover luxury items like expensive watches and cars, and prevent them from benefiting from their crimes. The message for victims is that reporting fraud matters - it helps build the intelligence picture that eventually leads to these criminals being caught and their assets being seized. Every report contributes to stopping these criminal networks.
source_document: Nigerian serial fraudster and British partner lose more than £1million of assets

instruction: I think someone might be using my identity to apply for credit cards. How can I protect myself?
output: This is a serious concern, but there are effective steps you can take to protect yourself. Contact CIFAS immediately to apply for protective registration - this puts extra security checks in place whenever someone tries to apply for financial services using your name and address. Monitor your credit report regularly through services like Experian, Equifax, or TransUnion to spot any accounts you didn't open. Contact your bank and any credit card companies to alert them about potential identity theft. If you find evidence that credit cards or accounts have been opened in your name without permission, report this to Action Fraud online or on 0300 123 2040, and also report it to your local police. Keep detailed records of all communications and any fraudulent applications you discover. Consider placing fraud alerts on your credit files. The case studies show that even sophisticated identity fraudsters can be caught and their assets seized, so reporting these crimes does lead to results. Act quickly - the sooner you put protections in place and report suspicious activity, the better you can limit any damage.
source_document: Nigerian serial fraudster and British partner lose more than £1million of assets

instruction: I want to report a fraud but I'm worried about creating an account online. Can I report anonymously?
output: You can absolutely report fraud without creating an account if that makes you feel more comfortable. When using Action Fraud's online reporting tool, you have three options: register for an account, log into an existing account, or continue as a guest. If you choose to continue as a guest, you can still make your report but you'll only receive updates by email or post rather than being able to track progress online. While registering does give you extra features like saving partially completed reports and tracking progress through your dashboard, the most important thing is that you report the fraud in whatever way feels right for you. You can also report by phone on 0300 123 2040 (Monday to Friday, 8am-8pm) if you prefer speaking to someone directly. Remember, their web chat is available 24 hours a day if you need help while reporting online. Your safety and comfort matter most - choose whichever reporting method feels best for you.
source_document: How to report fraud and cyber crime

instruction: I started reporting a fraud online but got interrupted. Will I lose all the information I entered?
output: If you registered for an account when you started your report, you're in luck - you can save and resume partially completed reports. Simply log back into your account, go to 'My account' and then 'My reports', and you should be able to continue where you left off. This is one of the helpful features designed to make reporting easier, especially for complex cases that might take time to document properly. If you didn't register and were reporting as a guest, unfortunately the information may not have been saved. However, don't let this discourage you from reporting - it's still worth completing a new report as it helps protect both you and others. The web chat feature is available 24 hours a day if you need help while filling out your report. Next time, consider registering at the start if you think you might need to take breaks while reporting. Your report is valuable regardless of how many attempts it takes to complete it.
source_document: How to report fraud and cyber crime

instruction: My business is being cyber attacked right now. Is there emergency help available?
output: Yes, there is emergency help available for live cyber attacks. Call Action Fraud immediately on 0300 123 2040 - this emergency service for businesses, charities, and organisations is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week when you're suffering an active cyber attack. Don't wait - call now while the attack is in progress. The advisors can provide immediate guidance to help you respond to the ongoing attack. Remember, if you suffer a data breach, you may also need to report it to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) within 72 hours under GDPR rules - you can do this at ico.org.uk. Action Fraud won't automatically pass your data breach report to the ICO, so you'll need to report to both organizations separately. The immediate priority is getting help to stop the attack, so call the emergency number right away. Keep records of what's happening as this will be important for both your cyber attack report and any potential data breach reporting requirements.
source_document: How to report fraud and cyber crime

instruction: I'm worried about what happens to my personal information when I report a fraud. Will it be kept secure?
output: Your concerns about data security are completely understandable, and Action Fraud takes protecting your information very seriously. When you make a report, they promise to only collect the information they need for the investigation, and they will protect it to ensure nobody who shouldn't have access can see it. Your personal information will only be shared with police or anti-fraud agencies who need it to investigate the crime and protect others. They will never make your personal information available for commercial use without your permission, and they won't keep it longer than necessary. If they do need to share your information with other organisations to give you better public services, they will let you know and, where possible, give you the option to say no. The data you provide is totally secure and follows all legal requirements including the Data Protection Act 2018. You have rights to know what information they hold about you and to ask for corrections if needed. Your privacy and data security are protected by law, and reporting fraud shouldn't add to your worries about personal information being misused.

instruction: I'm reporting a fraud on behalf of my elderly parent who has dementia. Will Action Fraud provide extra support?
output: Yes, Action Fraud provides enhanced services for vulnerable victims, which includes people suffering from mental disorders. When contacting Action Fraud on behalf of your parent, please make it clear that you're reporting on behalf of a vulnerable victim - this will trigger their enhanced service protocols. The Victims' Code recognizes that vulnerable victims need additional support, and Action Fraud is committed to providing the best possible service in these circumstances. They understand that elderly people with conditions like dementia can be particularly targeted by fraudsters and need special consideration. Everyone who reports fraud to Action Fraud has the option to receive ongoing support from Victim Support, a charity that provides free, confidential help. This partnership is central to their commitment to putting victims at the heart of the process. Your parent is fortunate to have you advocating for them. Don't hesitate to ask for the enhanced service - it's specifically designed for situations like this where someone needs extra care and attention during the reporting process.
source_document: Vulnerable victims and the Victims' Code

instruction: My teenage daughter was targeted by an online scam. Does she qualify for special victim support?
output: Yes, your daughter absolutely qualifies for enhanced victim support. Under the Victims' Code, anyone under the age of 17 at the time of the offence is automatically classified as a vulnerable victim and entitled to an enhanced service. This recognition acknowledges that young people may need additional support when dealing with crime, especially online scams which can be particularly confusing and distressing for teenagers. When you contact Action Fraud, make sure to mention that you're reporting on behalf of a vulnerable victim under 17 - this will ensure she receives the appropriate level of support. Action Fraud works in partnership with Victim Support, which offers free, confidential assistance specifically designed to help young victims cope with the impact of crime. There are also specialized resources available for young people, including Childnet International and the UK Safer Internet Centre, which provide education and support about online safety. Your daughter's age actually works in her favor here - she's entitled to extra protection and support that recognizes young people need different care when they're victims of crime.
source_document: Vulnerable victims and the Victims' Code

instruction: I'm in Scotland - can I still report fraud to Action Fraud?
output: If you're in Scotland, you should report fraud directly to Police Scotland rather than Action Fraud. Police Scotland has not signed up to the Action Fraud process, so they handle fraud reports differently in Scotland. You can find guidance on how to report scams and fraud on the Police Scotland website under their 'Scams and frauds' section. This is important to know because Action Fraud covers England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, but Scotland has its own system. If you're unsure about which agency to contact, you can always call Police Scotland on 101 for guidance. They'll be able to direct you to the right place and help you report the fraud properly. Don't let this difference in systems discourage you from reporting - it's just as important to report fraud in Scotland, and Police Scotland is well-equipped to help you.

instruction: I reported a fraud but haven't heard anything back. How can I get an update on my case?
output: If you registered on the Action Fraud website when you made your report, you can track its progress by logging into your account. After logging in, click on 'My account' in the top right corner and then click 'My reports' to see the status. If you didn't register at the time of reporting, unfortunately this tracking feature won't be available to you, but you should still receive an outcome notification in due course by email or post. If you have more questions about your report, you can use their web chat service which is available 24 hours a day. Remember that not all reports result in individual police investigations - some are used for intelligence purposes to build a bigger picture of fraud patterns, while others may be sent to prevention teams to block fraudulent phone numbers or websites. This doesn't mean your report isn't valuable - every piece of information helps protect others from similar scams.

instruction: I need to report something but I'm deaf and use British Sign Language. Can Action Fraud help me?
output: Yes, Action Fraud provides excellent support for deaf and hard of hearing people who use British Sign Language. They work with SignVideo, the UK's leading BSL video interpreting service, to help you report fraud. To use this service, download the SignVideo app on your mobile device. When you open the app, scroll down the SignDirectory until you find 'Action Fraud' and click on it. A qualified BSL interpreter will appear on your screen to help interpret your conversation with Action Fraud. To use SignVideo, you'll need a device with a camera (phone, tablet, or computer), a webcam (built-in or plugged-in), and a good internet connection (minimum 2mbps upload and download speed). The service works on 3G, 4G, 5G networks, WiFi, or wired broadband. If you have any technical issues, you can contact SignVideo customer services through their BSL service at customer.signvideo.me or email their technical support team. This ensures you have equal access to fraud reporting services and can get the help you need in your preferred language.

instruction: What types of crimes can't I report to Action Fraud? I'm not sure if my case qualifies.
output: Action Fraud specifically handles fraud and cybercrime reports, but there are several types of crimes they cannot take reports for. You cannot report theft of a vehicle, suspicious online behavior involving children, online hate or bullying, counterfeit medicine purchases, business or personal tax fraud, benefit fraud, immigration fraud, or counterfeit currency to Action Fraud. For vehicle theft, you should report to the police directly. For suspicious online behavior with children, contact CEOP (Child Exploitation and Online Protection). Online hate crimes should go to your local police. Tax fraud goes to HMRC, benefit fraud to the relevant benefits agency, and immigration fraud to the Home Office. Counterfeit currency should be reported to your local police station. If you're unsure whether your situation qualifies as fraud, it's worth calling Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040 anyway - they can guide you to the right organization if they can't help directly. Don't let uncertainty stop you from seeking help - it's better to ask and be redirected than not to report at all.

instruction: I want to withdraw my fraud report because I got my money back. Is this possible?
output: Yes, you can usually withdraw your fraud report if the circumstances have changed significantly from what you originally reported. Action Fraud commonly handles withdrawals when situations turn out differently than first thought. For example, if you reported online shopping fraud because goods didn't arrive, but they were simply delivered late or the seller provided a full refund for items they couldn't supply, this would be grounds for withdrawal. Similarly, if what you thought was a fraudulent bank transaction turned out to be a legitimate charge or a banking error that's been resolved, you can request withdrawal. Another common scenario is when you receive a full refund from your bank or payment provider after you've already reported the fraud. To request a withdrawal, contact Action Fraud and explain the changed circumstances. They'll need to confirm that the situation is indeed different from what was originally reported. Having your money returned is great news, and it's responsible of you to let them know so they can focus resources on cases where victims still need help.

instruction: I'm worried the fraudulent activity I experienced might be connected to terrorism funding. Should I still report to Action Fraud?
output: Yes, you should absolutely report this to Action Fraud, and it's important that you do. You may be right to be concerned - terrorists, like other criminals, sometimes need access to funds to help them plan activities. If you've noticed suspicious or unusual bank transactions, or if someone has passports or documents in different names for no obvious reason, these could be warning signs. Don't worry about potentially wasting police time or getting someone in trouble unnecessarily - you are not wasting anyone's time, and no call will be ignored. What you tell them is treated in strict confidence and thoroughly researched by experienced officers before any police action is taken. If you see or hear something unusual or suspicious, trust your instincts and act - Action Counters Terrorism. You can report your concerns to Action Fraud as normal, or you can also visit gov.uk/ACT to make an online report specifically about potential terrorism connections. When attacks have happened in the past, people often say they suspected something was wrong but hesitated to come forward. Your vigilance could be crucial in preventing serious crimes.

instruction: What actually happens to my report after I submit it to Action Fraud? Will police investigate my case?
output: After you submit your report to Action Fraud, it goes to the National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB) for assessment. The NFIB will analyze your report alongside thousands of others to build a clearer picture of fraud patterns across the UK. Experienced reviewers will assess whether there's enough information to send your case to a police force for investigation. However, it's important to understand that not all reports result in individual police investigations. Some reports are sent to forces as intelligence to help them take appropriate action, while others go to Prevention and Disruption Teams who can block fraudulent phone numbers or websites to prevent others becoming victims. Police forces cannot be compelled to investigate every case - they review each report and decide their course of action based on various factors. Even if your specific case isn't individually investigated, your report is valuable because it contributes to the intelligence picture that helps law enforcement understand fraud trends and protect future victims. Every report matters in the fight against fraud.

instruction: I registered on the Action Fraud website but didn't receive a confirmation email. What should I do?
output: This is a common issue that's usually easy to resolve. First, check your Spam or Junk email folder - confirmation emails sometimes get filtered there by mistake. If your email is set to automatically delete spam, also check your deleted or trash folder as the email might have ended up there. Sometimes it can take a few minutes for the confirmation email to arrive, so if you've just registered, wait a little longer before worrying. If you still can't find the confirmation email after checking all these places, call Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040 and they can help you resolve the registration issue. Don't let this technical problem prevent you from reporting fraud or accessing the useful features that come with registration, like tracking your report's progress and being able to add information later. The registration system is designed to make reporting easier for you, so it's worth getting this sorted out.

instruction: Can I send physical evidence like documents or items to Action Fraud with my report?
output: No, Action Fraud cannot accept physical correspondence or evidence when you make a report. However, this doesn't mean your evidence is worthless - you should definitely keep hold of any physical evidence you have, as it may be required later if there's a police investigation into your case. This includes things like fake documents, counterfeit items, suspicious letters, or any other physical evidence related to the fraud you experienced. Store these items safely and make sure they're properly labeled so you know what they relate to. If your case does get referred to police for investigation, they will contact you about any evidence they need. You can add information about what physical evidence you have when you make your online report, so investigators know it exists. The online reporting system is designed to capture all the important details digitally, but physical evidence can still play a crucial role if your case moves to formal investigation.

instruction: I made a report years ago before 2018 but can't access it on the new website. What happened to my case?
output: If you made your report before 6th October 2018, your case details are still on record, but the Action Fraud website has been upgraded since then. Unfortunately, the old NFRC reference number and password you were given won't work with the new website system, and registering on the new website won't give you access to your old report. This doesn't mean your report has been lost or forgotten - it's still in the system and being processed. Action Fraud aims to send updates within 4-6 weeks after a report is made, though this can sometimes take longer for complex cases. If you haven't received an update about your old report and you're concerned about its progress, you can call Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040 with your old reference number and they should be able to give you information about the status. The website upgrade was necessary to improve services, but they understand it can be frustrating not to be able to track older reports online.

instruction: I received a letter mentioning 'Falcon North' - what does this mean for my fraud case?
output: If you received a letter mentioning 'Falcon North' (or Falcon East, South, or West), this means your fraud report has been sent to the Metropolitan Police Service team that covers that particular area of London. Operation Falcon refers to the different geographical areas within the Metropolitan Police Service - North, East, South, and West cover different boroughs in London. This is actually positive news because it means your case has been assessed by the National Fraud Intelligence Bureau and deemed suitable to send to the relevant police team for their consideration. The specific Falcon area mentioned corresponds to where the fraud occurred or where key evidence points to. For example, if your letter mentions Falcon North, your case has been sent to the Metropolitan Police team covering the northern boroughs of London. This doesn't guarantee investigation, but it means your report has been taken seriously and passed to the appropriate local police team who can decide on the best course of action for your specific case.

instruction: English isn't my first language. Can I report fraud to Action Fraud in my own language?
output: Yes, Action Fraud runs a service in multiple languages to help people whose first language isn't English. This is important because fraud can affect anyone regardless of their language background, and everyone deserves to be able to report crimes in a language they're comfortable with. For more detailed information about what languages are available and how to access these services, you should visit the Action Fraud website at actionfraud.police.uk where they provide guidance on language support options. You can also call them on 0300 123 2040 to discuss what language support they can provide for your specific needs. Don't let language barriers prevent you from reporting fraud - Action Fraud recognizes that the UK is a diverse country and they're committed to making their services accessible to everyone. Getting help in your preferred language can make the reporting process much less stressful and ensure you can provide all the important details about what happened to you.

instruction: What is the National Economic Crime Victim Care Unit and how can they help me?
output: The National Economic Crime Victim Care Unit (NECVCU) is a specialist team within the City of London Police that provides enhanced support for vulnerable people who have been victims of fraud and cyber crime. Their main goals are to make you feel safer and reduce the likelihood of you becoming a repeat victim of fraud. The NECVCU team consists of specially trained advocates who understand the particular challenges faced by fraud victims, especially those who might be more vulnerable due to age, disability, or other circumstances. They can provide personalized support, practical advice, and help coordinate with other agencies to ensure you get comprehensive assistance. If you've been a victim of fraud and feel you might benefit from this additional support - particularly if you're worried about being targeted again or if the fraud has significantly impacted your confidence or wellbeing - you can ask about being referred to the NECVCU when you report to Action Fraud. This service recognizes that fraud can have lasting emotional and practical impacts beyond just the financial loss, and provides the extra care some victims need.
